ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Critical analysis of theatre and performance studies. A holistic approach, considering the breadth of sociocultural influence on art production, conception, and interpretation. Skills in group discussion and community collaboration on weekly writings. New approaches to developing performance utilizing mixed media. Develop an understanding of ethnographic and archival research approaches and their relationship to dance research.
I learned what it means to be an academic in theater, and to appreciate it beyond just the practice.
Developed skills to be able to do journal each week, learned about different impacts of performance, looking at the world through different vantage points.
This course taught me how to combine the practices of archival research and theater.
theatre history and readings primarily focused on activism and art
A lot about different aspects of theater and performance

I learned how to digest and comprehend performance theory and put that in conversation with contemporary and historical instances of performance. I practiced analyzing methods of performance and comparing how these different modes interact with one another and the world around them.
I learned a lot about performance theory, writing ethnographies, and dance history.
I learned some of the theory of performance studies and got to meet some faculty in the TDPS department.

I developed an understanding of several themes in performance studies, as well as knowledge about the scholars whose work live in each spaces. I also gained skills related to analyzing performances using those tools or theories.
Lots of insights about current political issues and the history of dance.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: student-centered learning, approachable administration, engaging assignments. 
Weaknesses: new assignments late or missing from Canvas sight.

Strengths: the guest lecturers were interesting and provided valuable insight

Weaknesses: sometimes it felt very lecture-y and disengaging

Strengths  good to have a lecture & section. Loved the guest speakers too. Really nice start into theater. Prof very supportive.
Weaknesses  sometimes class got a little long without a break but not really a weakness. Had a little trouble sometimes knowing if I really understood the content from the journals so maybe mid-semester feedback would be nice!

strengths --> great environment and supportive. classes and content was pretty simple, which I liked
weaknesses --> classes felt very similar each week, not much difference in classes. there were different guest speakers each week but it followed the same format which can be boring sometimes
The readings were a lot and often were dense.

Strengths - the most iconic teaching team! Professor Reid is an angel and Faith and Rebecca were both incredible TA's! Also the guest lectures were so cool and exposed me to so many interesting and new areas of performance studies that I had never heard of before--and now want to explore further. I hope with further interations of the class, there would be opportunites to do more fields trips/site visits/workshops with the artists or performance scholars who visit or are talked about. Weaknesses - the weekly discussion posts were often a bit stressful due to their length and the amount of reading required to complete them. Perhaps a lighter reading load or a shorter discussing length requirement would make things better.
The structure and academic goals could be clarified early on, making it easier to comprehend such dense theoretical material.

The course felt very unorganized, with not a lot of actual useful information. It was very concentrated on dance, which is not my area of interest within the TDPS major, so I felt like there wasn't a lot of academic benefit for me in the course. The 500 word weekly reading responses were way too long for an intro course, and section was really not necessary. The strengths of the course came in getting to meet other TDPS majors and faculty, and building those relationships throughout 111 was nice.

The strengths of the course is that you are able to learn a broad range of information by the end of the course and are introduced to several different theories and scholars. A weakness is that it can feel like the course moves very fast and things may be confusing until time is spent organizing all of the different performance theories that have been introduced.

The readings are very long, and it would be more productive to have shorter excerpts from the same sources. (I often found myself skimming.) It was sometimes unclear how what we were learning connected to theater and performance. 

The organization of the course is great, and there is continuity between lectures.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Only if you're interested in the major or eager to learn about performance studies. If you have no intention of majoring and you're just looking for a fun theater course, there are better options.
I would recommend this course to any student interested in historical and sociocultural research approaches to performance.
Yes, but only if theyre seriously interested in theater
Yes  just be prepared to do readings throughout the week rather than the day before. The guest speakers made me want to explore theater major from hearing all of the perspectives.
I would only recommend this class if you're considering the TDAPS major. Otherwise, there are better theater and performance courses for those interested in trying one out.
yes, if you are interested in theatre and theatre activism. as well as reading and making a final peformance on your own for the final
No, but it is a prerequisite for the major. It has a lot of theory and readings about dance and performance and the theater world.

I would if you are interested in getting a taste for performance studies or you are a Theater major, although it's not really as much about recommended as it is about required in that case. I really appreciated the direction Professor Reid took the class in, and I definitely learned a lot about performance as a mode of thinking. I also greatly appreciated a lot of the guest lectures, especially those that centered our own questions and opinions and worries about making art in the world. I thought the class was pretty good overall, and I feel it will only get stronger over time, especially with Professor Reid at the helm.

Yes, I would. It is an opportunity for theater makers to interact and learn about material that they may not otherwise come upon, and it is instrumental to expanding the performance mindset to interact with so many different instances of theater.
It's a great introduction to performance theory if you are interested in the subject.
Only if you have to take it to become a TDPS major.
Yes, I would recommend this course to students who are interested in the performance theory and scholarship side of theater studies.

Only to a theater major (or someone very interested in the politics of performance). I felt like there was a lot of busywork involved, so someone who didnt have the incentive of the major wouldnt want to do the weekly writing.
